definition: to take a risk out of desperation (idiom)
big arrow/walk fast
ingot
and/as well as/and so/but (not)/yet (not)/(indicates causal relation)/(indicates change of state)/(indicates contrast)
to walk/to go/to run/to move (of vehicle)/to visit/to leave/to go away/to die (euph.)/from/through/away (in compound verbs, such as 撤走[che4 zou3])/to change (shape, form, meaning)
danger/dangerous/rugged

sentences.english: In this case, they had to take risks, engage in Private Salt production.
sentences.chinese: 在此情況下，他們只好鋌而走險，從事私鹽生產。

sentences.english: Why do some journalists and media dare to take a risk?
sentences.chinese: 少數記者和新聞媒體爲何鋌而走險？

sentences.english: So many seekers risk, and some lose, their lives in pursuit of the Miami dream.
sentences.chinese: 許多邁阿密尋夢者鋌而走險，有人甚至成了亡靈。

sentences.english: Of Li Heping risk danger in desperation stimulate will conspiratorial have one's way.
sentences.chinese: 李和平鋌而走險的激將陰謀得逞了。

definition: to set a trap
to deceive/to conceal
to cross the sea by a trick (idiom)/to achieve one's aim by underhanded means
imprisonment
variant of 巨額|巨额[ju4 e2]
to use gain as a lure
drug dealer/drug trafficker
to escape (from prison)/to jump bail
unfettered and beyond the law (idiom); evading retribution/getting away with it (e.g. crimes)/still at large
ill-gotten wealth or gains
to be without a fixed residence (idiom)
to make a profit/to gain/to get an advantage
lit. beat the grass to scare the snake (idiom)/fig. to inadvertently alert an enemy/to punish sb as a warning to others
to oppose each other with equal harshness (idiom); tit for tat/measure for measure
to sell off (one's property)
to harbor hard feelings
